questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions:
a) Why is 21 February a memorable day in our national history?
b) Who is responsible to raise a storm of protest and how? Describe.
c) How did the Pakistani government try to prevent the protest?
d) What did the students of Dhaka University do against the declaration of outlạiving all sorts of public meetings and rallies?
e) How is Language Movement related to Independence Movement of Bángladesh?

sub_questions.explanation:
a. February 21 is a memorable day in our national history because on this day in 1952, the heroic son's of Bengal laid down their lives to establish Bangla as a state language of the undivided Pakistan. On this day, we pay tribute to the language martyrs because of their sacrifice for the rightful place of mother tongue.
b. The then Governor General of Pakistan, Mohammad Ali Zinnah, is responsible to raise a storm of protest. In a public meeting in Dhaka, he declared Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan, which disregarded the language rights of the Bangalee. Therefore, a mass protest started across the country.
c. The Pakistani government banned all sorts of public meetings and gatherings to stop the protest that began following Mohammad Ali Jinnah's declaration of Urdu as the only state language of Pakistan and continued non-stop.
d. Against the declaration of outlawing all sorts of public meeting and rallies, the students of Dhaka University brought out a peaceful protest procession on 21 February, defying the law.
e. The Language Movement of 1952 kindled the sparks of independence movement in East Pakistan by making the Bangalees aware of their rights. Thus, the Language Movement is related to the independence movement of Bangladesh.

questions.uddipok:
Answer the following questions to write a paragraph on "Deforestation". You should write it in about 150 words.
(a) What is deforestation? (b) What are the causes of deforestation? (c) What are the impacts of deforestation on human beings, fauna, nature and climate? (d) How will the low-lying countries be affected? (e) How can deforestation be prevented?

sub_questions.explanation:
Deforestation
Deforestation refers to the cutting and burning down of forests at random. It is just the opposite of the concept of tree plantation. In a word, it is the destruction of trees and plants in our environment. It has many adverse effects on our environment and oưr life. It destroys the ecological balance of our environment and our life. Due to deforestation, many species of birds and animals have already been extinct and many of them are faced with the threat of extinction. Because of deforestation, it does not rain adequately and this causes long-term drought. This drought may turn the whole country into a desert. Apart from this, deforestation also hampers our agricultural production. In fact, our environment is going to be uninhabitable for deforestation. However, there is a way to save ourselves and our environment from it and that is, we should start a mass campaign for tree plantation. For this, we should raise awareness among the mass people about the adverse sides of deforestation as well as about the importance of tree plantation. My suggestion, in this regard, is that we should plant at least one tree every month and if we cut one; we should plant three. I think. each man or woman, old or young should come forward and plant at least one tree to save our existence.

Read the beginning of a story below, It is not complete. Add at least ten new sentences to complete it. Give a suitable title to it.
Once there lived a poor woodcutter in a village near a jungle. He used to cut woods from the forest and sell it in the market. But one day, while cutting wood………..

sub_questions.explanation:
The Honest Woodcutter
Once there lived a poor woodcutter in a village near a jungle. He used to cut woods from the forest and sell it in the market. But one day, while cutting wood, his axe slipped from his hand and fell into a deep river nearby. The woodcutter became very sad because it was the only axe he had, and he could not afford a new one.
He sat on the riverbank and started crying. Suddenly, a kind fairy appeared from the water and asked him why he was crying. The woodcutter told her everything. The fairy dived into the river and came up with a golden axe . “Is this yours?” she asked. The woodcutter said, “No, this is not mine.”
Then she brought a silver axe and asked the same question. Again, the woodcutter replied, “No, that’s not mine either.” Finally, she brought his old iron axe , and he happily said, “Yes! That one is mine!”
The fairy was very pleased with his honesty and gave him all three axes as a reward. The woodcutter went home joyfully and lived happily ever after. His honesty brought him unexpected blessings.

22 April 2020

My heartiest compliments go to you. Hope, that you are hale and hearty. In your last letter you wanted to know about the co-curricular activities in my school.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Noha and your friend is Mahin. Now, write a dialogue between you and yout friend about the merits and demerits of using mobile phone at teenage.

sub_questions.explanation:
Noha: Hey Mahin! I was reading an article yesterday about how mobile phones affect teenagers. It got me thinking—do you think it's more helpful or harmful?
Mahin: Hey Noha! That’s actually a great topic. I think it’s a bit of both. Mobile phones are super helpful for staying connected and accessing information, but they also have their downsides.
Noha: Totally agree. Like, one of the biggest merits is easy communication. We can call, text, or video chat with friends and family anytime.
Mahin: Yeah, and educational apps and online resources make studying easier too. We can watch tutorials, join online classes, and even do research quickly.
Noha: Right. But on the flip side, many teens get addicted to social media and games. That really affects their studies and sleep.
Mahin: Exactly. And some even suffer from anxiety or low self-esteem because of comparing themselves to others on social media.
Noha: Another issue is less face-to-face interaction. I feel like teens are losing social skills because they’re always on their phones.
Mahin: True. Plus, spending too much time staring at screens can cause eye problems and other health issues.
Noha: But still, if we use mobile phones responsibly, they can be very useful. It’s all about balance, right?
Mahin: Definitely. Using phones wisely can make teenage life easier and more productive, but overuse can lead to serious problems.
Noha: Well said, Mahin. I think every teen should know both sides before using a phone too much.
Mahin: For sure. Awareness is the first step to using technology in a healthy way

Mother Teresa was moved by the sight of the sick and dying on the streets of Kolkata. She founded a home for the dying destitute and named it "Nirmal Hriday", meaning "Pure Heart". She and her fellow nuns gathered the dying people of the streets of Kolkata and brought them to this home. They were lovingly looked after and cared for. Since then men, women and children have been taken from the streets and carried to Nirmal Hriday. These unloved and uncared for people get an opportunity to die in an environment of kindness and love. In their last hours they get human and divine love, and can feel they are also children of God. Those who survive, the Missionaries of Charity try to find jobs for them or send them to homes where they can live happily for some more years in a caring environment. Regarding commitment to family, Mother Teresa said, "May be in our own family, we have somebody, who is feeling lonely, who is feeling sick, who is feeling worried, are we there? Are we willing to give until it hurts in order to be with our families, or do we put our interest first? We must remember that love begins at home and we must also remember that future of humanity passes through the family." Mother Teresa's work has been recognised thought the world and she has received a number of awards. These include the Pope John XXIII Peace Prize (1971), the Nehru Prize for Promotion of International Peace and Understanding (1972), the Balzan Prize (1978), the Nobel Peace Prize (1979) and the Bharat Ratna, (1980). Mother Teresa died at the age of 87, on 5 September 1997. The world salutes her for her love and compassion for humanity. She has taught us how to extend our hand towards those who need our love and support irrespective of creed, caste and religion.
